content.content: MatrisomeDB is a searchable database that integrates experimental proteomic data on the ECM composition of normal and diseased tissues. It provides for each entry the list of tissues in which it was detected, a coverage map indicating the peptides detected, as well as the list of post-translational modifications identified. It also provides live cross-referencing to gene and protein databases for every ECM and ECM-associated genes.

The 2019 release of MatrisomeDB was developed through a collaborative effort between the Naba lab in the Department of Physiology and Biophysics at the University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) and the Gao lab in the College of Pharmacy at UIC.

MatrisomeDB is part of the larger Matrisome Project, an effort initiated by Dr. Naba during her postdoctoral training in the laboratory of Dr. Richard Hynes at MIT, in collaboration with members of the Bioinformatics & Computing Facility at the Koch Institute for Integrative Cancer Research at MIT, and Karl Clauser and Steve Carr at the Proteomics Platform of the Broad Institute.

MatrisomeDB is expandable. If you have recently reported the results of a ECM proteomics study and would like to have your data integrated in MatrisomeDB, please contact us at matrisomeproject@gmail.com. Your data will help other researchers in the field to conduct better research. Together, we thrive. To submit your data, click HERE.
Contact:
If you would like to submit your data, please contact us.
For questions, concerns and potential collaborations, feel free to contact us.
matrisomeproject@gmail.com

8.content: More online MatrisomeDB tools coming soon...

content.content: MatrisomeDB is expandable!
If you have recently reported the result of an ECM proteomics study and would like to have your data integrated in MatrisomeDB, please contact us at below email
matrisomeproject@gmail.com
If your data are already despotited in a public repository member of the ProteomeXchange consortium such as PRIDE or MASSIVE, please send us the repository ID and a copy of your original publication.
If your data is not deposited in a public repository, please contact us and we will send you a link to upload the data.
Your data will help other researchers in the field to conduct better research.
Together, we thrive!
1. General query of MatrisomeDB:
Locate the Search box
http://matrisomedb.pepchem.org/static/tutorial/search_bar.png

General query of MatrisomeDB is performed by inputting either one or multiple gene symbols, a proteins description, or a tissue type in the Search box. General queries are case-insensitive and accept partial word matching.
Search by typing a single gene name, tissue, or description in the Search box. For example, 'COL1A1' or 'Breast'
Note: Partial gene names are also accepted, for example entering 'COL1' will return data on all the protein entries encoded by a gene whose symbol contains COL1, such as COL1A1 but also COL10A1, etc.
Search by typing multiple genes in the Search box. This can be done by inputting comma-separated gene symbols, for example, 'COL1A1,COL6A3,COL6A1' or use syntax 'genes=(COL1A1,COL6A3,COL6A1)'.
2. Searching MatrisomeDB using Option boxes:
The three Option boxes below the Search box can be further used to explicitly select specific Matrisome Categories, Species, and /or Tissues.
http://matrisomedb.pepchem.org/static/tutorial/option_box.png
Users can cancel their selection by holding Ctrl and left-click on the options to be deleted.
Example 1: Entering a partial gene name:
To see the distribution of proteins encoded by genes whose symbols contain 'COL4'
a) Type: COL4 in Search box and click the search button
http://matrisomedb.pepchem.org/static/tutorial/COL4_searchbox.png
b) The first panel displayed at the top of the Result page is the 'Organ system legend'. Its color code will match that of the tissue types listed at the right of the heatmaps.
http://matrisomedb.pepchem.org/static/tutorial/tissue_legend.png

c) The second panel on the Result page presents a hierarchically-clustered tissue distribution heatmap of all proteins encoded by gene containing in their symbols "COL4". Since the input is case-insensitive both human (COL4A1, COL4A2, COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5, COL4A6) and mouse (Col4a1, Col4a2, Col4a3, Col4a4) proteins will be displayed. The color code reflects the confidence score from low (yellow) to high (dark blue).
http://matrisomedb.pepchem.org/static/tutorial/COL4_heatmap.png
If you use MatrisomeDB for your research, please cite:
MatrisomeDB: the ECM-protein knowledge database. Shao X, Taha IN, Clauser KR, Gao Y, Naba A. Nucleic Acids Res. 2019 Oct 5. pii: gkz849.
http://doi.org/10.1093/nar/gkz849

Naba A#, Clauser K.R#, Hoersch S, Liu H, Carr S.A*, and Hynes R.O.* (2012) The matrisome: in silico definition and in vivo characterization by proteomics of normal and tumor extracellular matrices. Molecular and Cellular Proteomics, 11(4):M111.014647.
http://www.mcponline.org/content/11/4/M111.014647.long
Naba A*, Clauser K.R, Ding H, Whittaker C.A, Carr S.A, and Hynes R.O*. (2016) The extracellular matrix in the “omics” era. Matrix Biology, pii: S0945-053X(15)00121-3.
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.matbio.2015.06.003
For the complete list of publications of Dr. Naba on the Matrisome Project, click below
https://sites.google.com/a/uic.edu/nabalab/publications
